page.title: 13WESTFIELD MINE : PHYSICAL
page.content: Westfield is a rare example for the U.K. of a large and deep body of coal lying within comparatively easy reach of the surface. Its overall {overburden-to-coal ratio ( 5.33 to 1 ) is astonishingly{low for the U.K. } The pit reached at its{deepest point } some{250 metres}and covered an{area of {250 hectares.}At the bottom of the pit, a{coal seam over 50 metres thick} was exposed. The main reason why the deposit was not worked earlier was because a{peat} {bog}overlay a large part of the site, thus making access to the coal very difficult. The peat had to be dredged from the site before any excavations for the coal could begin. Much of this peat was dumped just to the west of Whinnyhall Farm - the area has been landscaped but it still creates marked feature on the land.
